content.question: The base of a solid is the region in the first quadrant bounded by the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the graph of <math alttext="y equals, 4 minus x squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. For this solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a rectangle whose height is <math alttext="6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> times the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate. What is the volume of the solid?

topic.text: 8.7: Volumes with Cross Sections - Squares and Rectangles

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
